We've been loyal and frequent customers since the early days and it's been a fantastic experience.
As with everything else, change is never fun especially if that means no more complimentary chips and salsa, now charged IF you want to opt-in for just over a $1 for a single portion.
We spent over $100 (this included a couple of Hot sauces to-go at 6.95 each >> well worth it) you would think that they would re-consider the chips and salsa based on customer spending.

Lines definitely gotten LONGER and can take well over 30-minutes before you can place your order (still worth it though).
The food does seem different, just can't tell if that Qty has been adjusted but again, taste has not changed at all and is still top notch.
Paid parking makes sense, DMV parking lot in the back is still free and available after 5pm and weekends.
I have not yet decided if I will reduce the frequency of visits or continue to try until they perhaps start charging for the hot sauces and seating. How did this place get a Michilin star? Food is fresh but it's just so-so. We tried $130 worth of food and unimpressed with half of it.
We liked smoked kanpachi tostada and pescado a las Brasas. Disapponited with the ceviches, pulpo taco, scallop taco and aguachiles. Service Dine in Meal type Dinner Price per person $30‚Äì50 Food: 2 Service: 4 Atmosphere: 3

My boyfriend and I got the ceviche de at√∫n, tostada de kanpachi + uni, erizo (live sea urchin with scallop), pata de mula (blood clams), and scallop aguachile.

The ceviche, tostada, and aguachile all had a repetitive flavor profile, with a heavy emphasis on citrus. It felt like we were tasting variations of the same dish, which got a little boring. The blood clams were a hard pass for me--they tasted like mole and just didn't sit well. The erizo was underwhelming; I was hoping for something more exciting.

One odd thing was the accompanying packets of crackers they gave with nearly all the dishes‚Äîthey just didn‚Äôt work well at all. I think these dishes are much better with tortilla chips instead. On the plus side, the food comes out quickly, and the line can get long, but it moves fairly fast. Just a heads-up that the service is kind of non-existent; it's pretty much self-serve. You have to get your own water, hot sauce, and napkins. When we asked one of the food runners for more napkins, she said yes but never came back.

The freshness of the seafood here is undeniable, but I wouldn't recommend going out of the way to try this place. Food: 3 Service: 2 Atmosphere: 2

Positive.Context:
This is a fantastic food and at a great price point for an one michelin star restaurant.  The atmosphere is nothing to write home about as it is in a food hall and you find your own table.  But you do not come here for the atmosphere...  It is the food.  The seafood is super fresh - you really can taste the freshness.  We ordered multiple tacos - baja fish, shrimp, octopus, grilled fish, grilled branzino, ceviche...  Each dish was great.  The price - ridiculously inexpensive... Came in with high hopes due to the Michelin rating and was not disappointed. My wife and I decided to do a huge sampling of whatever caught our eye on the menu.

The Spot Prawn and Scallop Aguachile was super fresh (prawns grabbed right out of the tank) and refreshing. The lime cilantro chile sauce was crisp and tasty with a hint of heat. Great summer dish.

Being a huge ceviche fan we had the Ceviche de Atun. The bluefin tuna was superb. Another well balanced crisp dish that you couldn‚Äôt stop eating.

The star of our meal though was the Tostada de Kanpachi & Uni. An absolute masterpiece. Beautifully layered textures and tastes. The uni was like icing on the cake to some amazing flavors. Even the tostada had amazing flavor. Would come back just for this dish!

The Pulpo a las Brasas was a pick of mine as I am a sucker for octopus. Super tender with a light char and smokiness. Not sure what the sauce was underneath but it was velvety smokey deliciousness. Even the side of cilantro rice and beans were top notch.

Tacos: We had the Baja Fish Taco and the Smoked Kanpachi Taco. Best fish taco I have ever had in my life. Fish was crisp and not greasy. Perfect amount of crema and salsa. The Kanpachi taco was delicious as well but the Baja taco was just a masterpiece of a taco staple. One thing that got my attention in both was the blue corn tortillas. This is what a tortilla is supposed to be. Never had such delicious tortillas in my life. Crazy how the smallest part of the dish can hold up everything and compete in flavor with the exotic ingredients.

Also enjoyed: we had the sparkling lemonade (tasted more like orange to me). Whatever was in it was amazing and refreshing. Not too sweet.

Pricing: who cares. I thought for the level of execution and the quality of ingredients the dishes would be a value at even a higher price point. Great value in my eyes.

Arguably one of the best restaurants I‚Äôve ever been to. Michelin starred for five years and rightfully so. There‚Äôs no glitz and glam just straightforward amazing food. It‚Äôs located in a food hall/market so you order at the counter and they bring the food to you, but there are a few counter seats available as well.
Everything was super fresh, which you can tell by the fresh fish that are on display in the cooler right behind the chefs. The staff is very helpful and attentive. We spoke with one of the owners Briana and you can tell she has a true passion for what she does.
We went here three nights in a row, not for lack of restaurant options as there are plenty to choose from in Los Angeles, but because it was just an amazing experience all around.
We tried the scallop Agua Chile, several of the tostadas, all the tacos, the grilled kanpachi collars, coctel de camarones, the scallop and Uni ceviche, and several other dishes. Every single, one of them deserves perfect reviews. Their freshly made blue corn tortillas alone are worth the trip.
Prices are very modest and won‚Äôt break the bank for the quality of food and service that you receive. Add this to your must try list for the next time you‚Äôre in LA. Came to this place while in town yesterday and have been wanting to try this since watching an episode of a food show on Youtube they were featured on. This honestly has to be top 5-10 best meals I've ever had in my life. Seriously. The seafood is so fresh and melts in your mouth. I had the garlic butter shrimp plate with the grilled bread, cilantro rice, and beans, and the flavor of the shrimp sauce was AMAZING. Since I was hungry, I had an array of different items, including the Tostada with the Kampachi, shrimp, and another fish, and it was out of this world!! The salsas are soooo good! The guacamole was cool (maybe needed a pinch of salt). But the showstopper were the CHURROS. Oh my god!!! Those Churros with the chocolate sauce? INSANE!!! Honestly, I'm going back again before I leave but seriously, this place is beyond words. The prices are reasonable but also range, depending on the dish and it's worth every penny. This place is deserving of its Michellin star and more. Thank you for creating this magical place. Holbox, I love you!!! Food: 5 Service: 5 Atmosphere: 5

The internet steered us to Holbox and wow I am glad that it did! Located in a nondescript food court/mall, Chef Gilbert Centina and his team serve elevated Mexican seafood. I've eaten excellent food in Mexico City and this is comparable in quality to the best I tried over there. This restaurant could easily be located in a fancy venue with significantly more expensive prices, so it's to the great fortune of Los Angeles (and tourists like myself) that it isn't.

We had the kanpachi (smoked fish) and uni tostada, baja fish and pulpo en su tinta (octopus in calamari ink sofrito) tacos, and ceviche (catch of the day ‚Äî we had tuna). The seafood was all incredibly fresh and delectable. I'm not a fan of octopus but I knew that Holbox makes a good one, and sure enough it had the light flakiness of a delicate fish. There was no "fishy" flavour and the sauces were thoughtful and complemented the meat well (I particularly enjoyed the ink sauce that accompanied the octopus taco).

The table also has five different hot sauces, which are fun to eat with the chips and salsa served before the meal.

We arrived ten minutes before opening and didn't need to wait in line. There was consistently a line the entire time we were there, but it seemed to be moving quickly.

One last thing: shout out to the Oaxacan place across the aisle in the food court that makes an awesome cafe de olla! I come back here for the Baja Fish Taco. I've tried a few other things on the menu, that were on point as well, I mean even the salsa that comes with the chips is bangin'. But no lie, I've never had a better fish taco than the one they serve here. Holbo is killing it over at Mercado La Paloma. The line goes out, and around back of the building. But its well worth the wait. I'd like to give a shout out to to all the staff. This is a fantastic food and at a great price point for an one michelin star restaurant.  The atmosphere is nothing to write home about as it is in a food hall and you find your own table. We ordered multiple tacos - baja fish, shrimp, octopus, grilled fish, grilled branzino, ceviche...  Each dish was great.  The price - ridiculously inexpensive... Came here with a friend for lunch on Friday and this place totally deserves its Michelin star. We got there about 15 minutes before opening, so parking was easy and we were part of the first group in line.

Holbox serves Yucat√°n-style seafood tacos, and every single one we tried was incredible. We ordered the scallop taco, octopus taco, smoked kanpachi taco, Baja fish taco, and the aguachile with spot prawn and scallops. The scallop was buttery and sweet, the octopus was super tender with that perfect char, and the smoked kanpachi had this deep, smoky flavor that was just insane. The aguachile was bright, spicy, and refreshing‚Äîperfect for a warm day.

The service was exceptional. You order at the counter, and they somehow manage to bring everything out quickly and perfectly timed, even with so many tables scattered around the market. It‚Äôs impressive how smoothly everything runs.

We finished with the churros and chocolate sauce, which were the perfect ending‚Äîcrispy, light, and the chocolate was rich but not overly sweet.

The small lot is paid (about $4 an hour), but there‚Äôs some free street parking if you get lucky. Definitely worth coming a little early for a spot.

Can‚Äôt wait to come back and try more of the menu, especially anything with uni. This place is a gem. After a serious ceremony at Malibu Beach, I decided to have something special. Then the nightmare started. It was only about 28 miles, but I spent almost two hours to arrive at Holbox. I don't know why the traffic was so horrible that day, or maybe it was just as normal as every day.

For friends who know me, I don't go to fine dining frequently. I had too much fine dining back in Shanghai. I'd rather find interesting dining spots--inside food courts, at food trucks, etc. Holbox is a Michelin one-star restaurant, but not pricey. Even though it's in a food court and not a traditional restaurant, it's interesting. The food booth doesn't have its own tables in the food court; they're shared with others.

It's a Mexican food booth. The boss lady--puebla in Spanish--was tough, but not rude. As with most Michelin spots, there was a queue, but it wasn't too long. I grabbed a table stand and found us a place to sit.

Not long after, the food was served. The free tortilla chips had no shining points--just as normal as in every Mexican restaurant. Crispy, flat dipping, better than nothing. Good for snacking after a long drive.

The food was served one by one, or you could say delivered one by one:

Erizo 5/5
The word erizo in Spanish means hedgehog, but it can also mean sea urchin. They actually look quite similar. Basically, it's sea urchin. Not everyone likes it--some love it, some hate it. I'm a big fan, uni in Japanese. There were two sea urchins, each with about four or five roes. Underneath were fish and scallop ceviches, but different from normal ceviche--it was lighter, without vinegar or lemon taste, more pure raw seafood. I liked it. Not cheap at $27 for an appetizer.

Taco de Pulpo en su Tinta (Octopus Taco) 5/5
Basically, it's an octopus taco, mixed with squid ink or cuttlefish in--I couldn't tell. The ink mostly gave it color, with just a faint hint of the sea for flavor. Each taco had a giant octopus tentacle--three tacos on a plate, one tentacle for each. The texture was excellen--soft, tender, not juicy but still moist, not fishy at all. I bet the octopus was stewed for a long time, which made it so tasty. Very good. $7 for three, which I wouldn't call expensive--actually well priced.

Pescado a las Brasas 5/5
Fish, who doesn't like fish? A few-bone fish, no tiny bones. The seabass had only one big bone but no tiny bones between the muscles. It was grilled seabass, not heavily marinated but well seasoned. The freshness was its biggest strength.

Cilantro Rice and Black Beans 5/5
The rice was served with the grilled seabass, dipped in stewed black beans. I had never tried that before, but it was tasty. Not too much cilantro aroma, but still good. The rice itself was perfectly cooked--grains separated, not sticky. Paired with the black beans, it was a great match.

I recommend this food booth in the food court, not only because of its Michelin crown, but also for the way they used squid/cuttlefish ink, how they treated cilantro, lemon, and avocado. They truly put heart into making good food. ‚Ä¢	The fresh sea urchin served right in the shell was creamy and sweet, a true taste of the ocean.
‚Ä¢	The grilled octopus with green rice and black beans had a wonderful char and tender bite.
‚Ä¢	And the octopus ceviche was light, citrusy, and refreshing with a touch of avocado for creaminess.

Service was warm and welcoming, and the colorful tiled tables made the whole experience feel festive and authentic.

If you‚Äôre looking for outstanding seafood with a creative Mexican twist, Holbox is absolutely worth the trip. Highly recommended Food: 5 Service: 5 Atmosphere: 5

Ordered for two people:
- Tostada de mero $11
- Scallop aguachile $16
- Ceviche mixto $20
- Smoked kanpachi taco $7
- Scallop taco $5
- Filete al carbon $16
- Onsite parking: < $3 for one hour
- Total: about $90, or ~$45/person with leftovers

The aguachile and ceviche had the same mild flavor but with different proteins, so it would have been sufficient to have ordered one or the other. The octopus in the ceviche was tender unlike other places that are rubbery and hard to chew, nor was it fishy, so you know it's fresh.

The kanpachi taco was a bit too salty.

The green rice that came with the filete al carbon was surprisingly tasty and actually one of our favorite parts.

The salsas are extremely spicy (rare and appreciated) and best to use as a few droplets rather than lather over the tacos.

As for the experience, we had read that the lines would be long and went with flexible expectations and acknowledged that it was a possibility we may arrive and not have a chance to try it. Arrived around 11:30 AM on a Thursday and the line was out the door. The parking lot and street parking were full and people there said it would be about an hour wait so we got a printed menu to go (since it changes every day). We did not feel comfortable leaving our cars so far away from view so we stayed inside it, reviewed the menu, called to order, and waited 45 minutes for the food. When we returned to pick up the food, we managed to get a parking spot as a person left. We chose parking for one hour for around $2.75 since 2 hours was around $8. Since it's a food court, we were able to eat our "to-go" food anywhere except at the Holbox bar.

This was our first Michelin star experience and probably one of the most affordable options out there, so we'll definitely recommend it for budget-conscious people looking for exceptionally fresh and quality ingredients. However, the flavor itself was pretty mild and parking is extremely limited, so be prepared to pay with your time (maybe get in line first at 10:30 AM before it opens). If you're looking for a seafood experience that feels like a quick trip to the coast of Mexico without leaving California, Holbox is a must-visit. This hidden gem delivers on bold, coastal flavors with an elevated twist.

I tried the uni and scallop tostada, and it was absolutely mind-blowing‚Äîso fresh, bright, and beautifully balanced. The wood-grilled octopus was cooked to perfection, tender with just the right char, and the taco de pulpo had this incredible smoky depth that lingered pleasantly.

You can tell the chef puts a lot of care into the ingredients and presentation. The vibe is casual but refined‚Äîperfect for food lovers who want serious flavor without all the fuss.

Don‚Äôt skip the agua frescas or the Baja-style oysters. Every bite and sip felt authentic yet innovative. Holbox is a standout for seafood and one of LA‚Äôs best-kept culinary secrets. Food: 5 Service: 5 Atmosphere: 5

Holbox has earned its Michelin one-star recognition year after year, and honestly, it‚Äôs easy to see why. The flavors are bold, fresh, and layered ‚Äî and the prices are still super reasonable. Just be ready to wait a bit on weekends, especially during peak hours.
üî• Must-tries
Taco de Pulpo en su Tinta ‚Äì Not just stunning to look at (hello black taco shell), but packed with flavor. The octopus is tender, and while it leans salty, the squid ink base gives it a deep, savory vibe ‚Äî almost like olive tapenade.

üî• Ceviche Mixto ‚Äì Bright, zesty, and super refreshing. Octopus, shrimp, and sea bass come together with citrus in a way that‚Äôs perfect for anyone who loves sashimi or raw bar bites.

üî• Tostada de Kampachi + Uni ‚Äì
This is your treat yourself moment. Rich, luxe, and ridiculously good.
The casual counter setup at Mercado La Paloma adds to the charm ‚Äî it‚Äôs not fancy, but the food easily rivals upscale spots.

üí° Pro tip: Come early, grab a drink while you wait, and make it a mini food adventure. Holbox has earned its Michelin one-star recognition year after year, and honestly, it‚Äôs easy to see why. The flavors are bold, fresh, and layered ‚Äî and the prices are still super reasonable. Just be ready to wait a bit on weekends, especially during peak hours.
üî• Must-tries
Taco de Pulpo en su Tinta ‚Äì Not just stunning to look at (hello black taco shell), but packed with flavor. The octopus is tender, and while it leans salty, the squid ink base gives it a deep, savory vibe ‚Äî almost like olive tapenade.

üî• Ceviche Mixto ‚Äì Bright, zesty, and super refreshing. Octopus, shrimp, and sea bass come together with citrus in a way that‚Äôs perfect for anyone who loves sashimi or raw bar bites.

üî• Tostada de Kampachi + Uni ‚Äì
This is your treat yourself moment. Rich, luxe, and ridiculously good.
The casual counter setup at Mercado La Paloma adds to the charm ‚Äî it‚Äôs not fancy, but the food easily rivals upscale spots.

üí° Pro tip: Come early, grab a drink while you wait, and make it a mini food adventure. If you're looking for an unforgettable dining experience, Holbox is the place to be. From the moment we walked in, we were greeted with warm, friendly service and a cozy atmosphere that perfectly blends casual with chic. The ambiance set the tone for what would be an amazing meal.

Now, let's talk about the food ‚Äì wow! We tried a variety of tacos, and each one was better than the last. The fish taco was incredibly fresh, with a perfect balance of flavors. The shrimp taco was cooked to perfection, plump and juicy, with just the right amount of seasoning. But the real standout for me was the octopus taco ‚Äì tender and smoky, it had an incredible depth of flavor that really impressed us.

We also had the uni ‚Äì it was beyond amazing. Fresh, creamy, and melt-in-your-mouth delicious, it was a true treat for seafood lovers. Each bite was a reminder of just how high the quality of ingredients is at Holbox.

The tacos alone are worth a visit, but we also couldn‚Äôt resist the cocktails, which were perfectly crafted and paired so well with the meal. The staff was attentive but never overbearing, and we felt like they genuinely cared about our experience.

Overall, Holbox is one of those spots where you know you‚Äôre going to get high-quality food and service every time. I‚Äôll definitely be coming back to try more of their delicious dishes ‚Äì it‚Äôs worth every penny! The food tastes fresh every time, and the dishes are packed with flavor. I will be coming back. A Michelin rated counter restaurant serving fresh, fresh seafood. In a Mexican food court close to USC and a mere few blocks from the USC/Jefferson Metro stop. Wait in line to order your dishes (grab a menu and be decisive), take a number and find a table.  If seats are open at the counter, grab them. We arrived at 2:30 and no counter seats but by the time we were finished several had opened up.  So if you want to sit at the counter, wait to order until you get a seat.  You still have to order!  Tried the sea urchin with scallops, octopus taco, ceviche mixto, and branzino filet.  All delicious.  There is a parking lot adjacent if you drive.  I think it's free. 3.5/5. I‚Äôm a bit spilt on Holbox. Many rave about it as it has a Michelin recognition. The food is very fresh as it‚Äôs constantly rotating due to the high demand. The menu is somewhat unique and there‚Äôs definitely interesting, palatable flavors and ingredients. However, it wasn‚Äôt overly delicious or unique enough to scream home about. You could have similar Mexican seafood experience in other mom and Pop restaurants around town. Personally, it wasn‚Äôt worth the hype.

There‚Äôs an attempt to have fast service, but you won‚Äôt be able to avoid the hour long wait. Longer, including getting your food. The place is located inside a packed and busy food hall, so it can be a struggle to find your own table. Another big thing is sanitation. Due to the high demand, there wasn‚Äôt a meticulous practice on keeping the stations, food prep, and cross contamination clean. I'm still thinking about the pulpo I had there! This place had some very very fresh ceviche. Highly recommend. We weren't expecting to sit at the bar, but they had some seating open (it's very limited). Great service. The home made lemonade is perfectly refreshing. For being Michelin starred, I think one comment is that the two ceviches we got had the same type of flavor. I couldn't really tell the flavors apart between fishes because it was covered by the same ceviche flavor profile. It was delicious nonetheless, but I wonder if other fish dishes on the menu are the same...as I said, I still think about the pulpo. Perfect char, accompanied by the perfect sauce. Ok, I didn't expect too much from a restaurant with a walk-up counter, and after spending a half-hour waiting in line, my first visit, I was curious what the buzz in the air was. We found a seat in the food court, and a short time later my grilled octopus dinner plate, my wife's three tacos, and the sea urchin and scallop ceviche arrived. Looks impressive, but would it hit the mark?
YES!!! I must say the food far surpassed any expectations I may have had!!!  So much so, I took the 30-mile trip from home again last weekend to try some more Holbox food. This time, I enjoyed the mixed seafood cocktail and three tacos (Baja, aged hamachi, and octopus). My wife went for the grilled octopus plate.
In one word, YUM!!!
It will not be long before we return again!
I rank the food as a 5, the service as a 4 (only because I prefer sit-down and waiter service,  and atmosphere a 3 because I think this food deserves a classier spot, but for the quality of the fare, you can't beat the price!

Holbox might just be the best food court or fast-casual dining experience you‚Äôll ever have. The quality coming out of this kitchen far exceeds what you‚Äôd expect from a counter-service setup‚Äîit‚Äôs almost a mismatch in the best possible way.

Ordering was smooth and easy, and the food arrived quickly. Chips and salsa were served first, which was a nice touch while we waited for the main dishes.

The setting can be seen as either charming or simply casual, but either way, there‚Äôs ample seating in the food court, so finding a table isn‚Äôt an issue.

While I personally find this style of casual dining a bit unglamorous‚Äîand wish I could enjoy a cold beer with my ceviche‚ÄîI recognize that the stripped-down setup keeps overhead low, and that value is clearly passed on to the customer. Wife and I went for early dinner around 3:30 on Sunday (1/19/25). Got a parking spot right away. There was already a 20 deep line just for Holbox. Ordered around 4 pm the grilled octopus plate (pulpo a las brasas), grilled kanpachi collars and a cold halibut tostada (tostada de lenguado). Attentive servers delivered chips and salsa right away. Food started arriving in 20 minutes. Halibut tostada was awesome and fresh. Octopus plate with habanero sauce was just the best...no rubbery morsel here!!! My wife thoroughly enjoyed the fish collar. In between, the wait staff were quick to add a baja fish taco my wife wanted to try. I would go back just to have the same dishes let alone try other items on the menu!! Gave ambiance only 4 stars because Holbox wasn't the only restaurant in the mercado plaza...but it was the primary attraction. BTW, when we left around 5:30 the line was even longer!! What can one say about Holbox? It is in a big food court. It has gotten a lot of press, and has a Michelin star. I will start with the food, but I have a lot to say about the experience.

You can upload the menu on your phone or get someone in your group to grab a menu. It is good to use your wait time in the long line to the ordering counter wisely. Send others to grab drinks from another vendor. Buy a few tacos from another vendor if you are hungry.

We tried a lot of dishes. The Baja shrimp taco is traditional, but the shrimp are huge and moist, and the crema and toppings are great. Also quite good was the tostado de jurel. It is yellowtail ceviche, avocado, and an almond salsa on a very crispy corn tortilla base. It was fresh, sour, savory, and yummy. I found the scallop aguachile to be a bit too lime forward, which tends to drown out the sweetness of scallops, but if you eat it with the pieces of avocado and chips, it mellows everything out. Needless to say, all the seafood is bright and fresh.

My companions really loved the smoked kanpachi tacos, all hot and cheesy, and spicy. The camarones al mojo were sensational. This is a main dish platter, so comes with excellent black beans and cilantro rice, plus toasted bread for sopping up the marinade. The shrimp were HUGE and perfectly prepared. So all in all, the food is terrific.

So the downsides: You will pretty much have a 30 to 45 minute wait before you can order. You will need to hunt out a table in the loud, noisy, and not very clean dining hall. The food comes out in no particular order. This makes the actual dining rather chaotic. Our 6 items cost over $100. Michelin star or not, to me, how I am served and the atmosphere in which I eat makes a difference. Is the food great? Yes. Does eating it amid the chaos make it less nice? Yes, absolutely.

I have eaten at a lot of Michelin started restaurants all over the world. Does this rate a Michelin star? I don't think so. But I do recommend eating here. The food is just terrific. Fresh wood-grilled fish is the best, but I often get their Baja style tacos or the scallop taco.   Civeches are wonderful. The fish soup is also excellent with its various seafood content. Many other wonderful dishes, oysters, cocktail,  branzinos. Earned Michelin Bib Gourmand two years in a row. One of the best seafood restaurants in Los Angeles without the hefty prices. Situated  in the Mercado la Paloma. I highly recommend this place. Chef Gilberto has been nominated for the James Beard Award for Chef of the year. Holbox is expanding its counter space for more seating and an open kitchen concept. HOLBOX was no. 1 Los Angeles restaurant last year and is no. 5 this year. It has also earned a Michelin Star this year
This is no small feat and tells of incredible and tasty foods and a testament to the creativity of Chef Gilberto. Closed on Mondays, otherwise the line to order food is constant. Come and try it! Service Dine in Meal type Lunch Price per person $20‚Äì30

We dropped by around 1 PM for lunch, wow the parking here was a bit of a challenge.  Once we got that, there was a line to order, that wasn't too bad but was roughly about 20 minutes overall.

We were lucky enough to be next in line with counter seating opening up for two people.  Once there, the wait staff took our order right away and we were given chips and salsa to munch on while we waited.

Taco De Pulpo En Su Tinta - Amazingly soft, well seasoned and extremely tasty.  A must order.

Scallop Aguachile - A bit tart, but so refreshing and perfect melding of flavor and texture between the scallops and avocado.  A very recommended order.

Erizo Sea Urchin Uni - Incredibly fresh sea urchin atop fish and scallops ceviche?  Who says no to that?  A very recommended order.

Sopa De Mariscos - I'm not a good judge of seafood soups because I love them all, but I feel confident in saying this is maybe one of the best I've ever eaten.  Make sure you dip that grilled bread, I think it's the best way to enjoy this dish honestly.  A must must order.

Oh, don't forget to order the Sparkling Lemonade.

Overall we had a great meal there and are already planning our next visit. A great find near USC‚Äôs campus. Holbox is located in a larger food hall, and although there was a line, it moved quickly. This was the best food I‚Äôve had in LA so far ‚Äî we ordered fairly reasonably priced items and felt incredibly satisfied leaving. I was able to have perfectly crunchy and soft bites of the Baja Fish Taco, which tasted even more delicious topped with the extra hot sauces that are provided by the counter. I also got to try the Baja Shrimp Taco which offered very different flavors, but made you feel like you were eating seaside. The Filete al Carbon was another good one ‚Äî plenty of beans and rice and avo with a healthy filet of branzino. Would recommend splitting a few different dishes if you‚Äôre going with someone else! The market was bustling but we found seating easily and it was enjoyable to be around other people that were loving the taste of their food, too. Seems like a great place for lunch, a casual date, or just a fun outing with kids! I‚Äôm dying to go back‚Ä¶ Service Dine in Meal type Lunch Price per person $10‚Äì20 Food: 5 Service: 5 Atmosphere: 5 Recommended dishes Fresh Seafood, Chips & Salsa Kid-friendliness As noted, this hall has a lot of different vibes, making it great for kids to people watch or just chill. The amount of stimulation is great for kids, although they may not be satisfied without dessert when they notice some of the other options!

‚ÄúA Culinary Symphony: Tacos that Transcend Reality!‚Äù

Oh, Holbox, you ethereal beacon of culinary excellence! Nestled within the vibrant Mercado La Paloma, this unassuming gem has redefined my understanding of what it means to truly live. I came here for a simple business meeting, but little did I know, I was about to embark on a gastronomic journey so profound that it would forever change the way I perceive the humble taco.

Let me start with the fish tacos‚Äîoh, the fish tacos! These aren‚Äôt just tacos, my friends; these are divine creations, descended from the heavens, kissed by the sea, and delivered to your plate with the grace of a thousand angels. The fish, perfectly crisp on the outside, yet tender and succulent within, was embraced by a tortilla so divine it could be the fabric of the gods themselves. And that ceviche? A burst of oceanic bliss that sent my taste buds into an ecstatic frenzy, dancing and singing praises to the culinary gods!

I found myself utterly mesmerized, unable to focus on the matters of business at hand. My associate, equally ensnared by the spell of Holbox, could only nod in agreement as we devoured these masterpieces in a shared state of euphoria.

But, alas, the path to paradise is not without its trials. The parking situation? A labyrinthine ordeal, forcing me to traverse nearly 300 meters from my vehicle to the gates of this culinary Eden. The prices? Not for the faint of heart, but let me assure you, every single penny was worth the price of admission to this nirvana of flavor.

And yes, the wait‚Äîoh, the wait‚Äîwas long and torturous. Yet, like a true pilgrimage, the reward at the end was nothing short of transcendent. This is one of those rare places where the hype is not just met but exceeded in every possible way.

So, to all my fellow food lovers, hear me now: Being a foodie may be a euphemism for being a little greedy, but at Holbox, it‚Äôs an indulgence that will feed your soul. Go forth, and eat those tacos, my friends. Eat those tacos!

Website: Holbox Los Angeles

Holbox is an absolute gem! Went there the other night and finally understand why it got that Michelin nod for 2024. The vibe is relaxed, yet the food is out of this world.

We ordered a bunch of tacos to try: Smoked Kanpachi Taco - wow, the smoky flavor was just right. Then there was the Taco de Pulpo en su Tinta, which was an explosion of rich, tangy ink sauce paired with perfectly cooked octopus. The Taco de Pescado al Carbon had that amazing char-grilled flavor, and the Scallop Taco - so tender and fresh, I honestly wanted another round of those. The Baja Fish Taco didn‚Äôt disappoint either; crispy and flavorful, just how it should be.

For sharing, we got the Pulpo A Las Brasas and Coctel Mixto. The grilled octopus (Pulpo A Las Brasas) was a standout - tender, with a crispy exterior and packed with flavor. The Coctel Mixto was a delightful, refreshing mix of seafood that balanced out the richer dishes perfectly.

Overall, Holbox delivered an incredible dining experience with every single dish. It‚Äôs definitely a must-visit for anyone looking to explore high-end Mexican fusion food. Can't wait to go back and try more! Service Dine in Meal type Lunch Price per person $20‚Äì30 Food: 5 Service: 5 Atmosphere: 5

Holbox Los Angeles is an exceptional culinary destination that delivers a high-quality dining experience, worthy of its Michelin star. Nestled within Mercado la Paloma, a historic landmark brimming with culture and a variety of unique food offerings, this restaurant provides a unique and memorable dining experience.

I began my meal with the Taco de pulpo en su tinta, a delightful dish featuring braised and fried Gulf of Mexico octopus. The octopus was tender and perfectly cooked, enhanced by the rich, savory calamari ink sofrito. The depth of flavor in this dish was outstanding, with each bite revealing a nuanced blend of textures and tastes that truly highlighted the quality of the ingredients.

Next, I indulged in the Scallop taco, a masterpiece of pan-seared Maine diver scallops. The scallops were succulent and cooked to perfection, accompanied by a vibrant salsa "x'catic" that added a touch of heat. The caramelized onions, tomato, and marinated fennel provided a sweet and tangy contrast, elevating the overall flavor profile of the dish. The combination of these elements created a harmonious and sophisticated taste that lingered pleasantly on the palate.

The C√≥ctel mixto was another highlight, featuring a mix of wild Mexican shrimp, Gulf of Mexico octopus, and Baja bay scallop. The seafood was fresh and succulent, and the house-made sweet and sour cocktail sauce added a refreshing and zesty touch. The balance of sweetness and acidity in the sauce complemented the natural flavors of the seafood beautifully, making this dish a refreshing and satisfying option.

The ambiance at Holbox is charming and laid-back, set within the vibrant environment of Mercado la Paloma. The market itself is a treasure trove of cultural experiences, offering a diverse array of food choices. It's a great place to explore and soak in the rich cultural tapestry of Los Angeles.

Holbox's approach to customer service is unique, with a casual system where food and drinks are dropped off at your table, rather than traditional waiter service. This setup adds to the relaxed atmosphere, allowing diners to enjoy their meal at their own pace without the formality of a traditional restaurant.

Overall, my experience at Holbox was delightful. Each dish showcased a thoughtful blend of high-quality ingredients and innovative flavors, making it clear why this establishment has earned a Michelin star. The ambiance and service add to the experience, making it a must-visit for anyone looking to explore the rich culinary landscape of Los Angeles. Seafood Extravaganza üíØ

Mercado La Paloma is situated within walking distance of the USC campus

This neighborhood gem features a small, but mighty, selection of authentic Mexican restaurants of which the most celebrated is Holbox

Featuring coastal seafood from Mexico, Holbox has a stellar selection of fresh seafood prepared and delivered daily so when Chef Celina suggested we wait for 10 minutes for the live Santa Barbara uni delivery, we listened

NorCal has nothing like this and I really loved everything from the casual counter space to the front row view of all the specialties being plated

Favorites include the live sea urchin and scallop ceviche and the live spot prawn tiradito, but everything is fresh, made to order and delicious

üì∑ Erizo $27 ~ Sea Urchin And Scallop Ceviche / Tiradito de Cameron $36 ~Iive spot prawn, fried shrimp heads, fish roe / Oysters 6 piece $20 / Tostada de Kanpachi + Uni $22 / Baja Fish Taco $5 / Smoked Kanpachi Taco $7 / Churros con Chocolate $7

Chef Gilberto Cetina draws deeply from his Yucat√°n roots to create a seafood-marisquer√≠a experience that feels both authentic and elevated. The menu features ceviches, tostadas, aguachiles and tacos, all built around fresh, well-sourced local seafood with bold citrus, chile and brine flavors.

Located inside Mercado La Paloma in South-Central L.A., a food-hall environment, Holbox is unpretentious and energetic but still delivers on incredible high-end cooking.

The restaurant has earned major recognition: a Michelin star (2024) and a ranking in the top echelon of LA and North America‚Äôs best restaurants.

Reservations are an absolute must and are next to impossible to get given the limited number of counter seats. A fair amount of persistence will be required to dine here.

For those in LA craving top-tier seafood, a pilgrimage to Holbox is an absolute must. Note that service is brisk and all dishes are served at the same time. Came here with a friend for lunch on Friday and this place totally deserves its Michelin star. We got there about 15 minutes before opening, so parking was easy and we were part of the first group in line.

Holbox serves Yucat√°n-style seafood tacos, and every single one we tried was incredible. We ordered the scallop taco, octopus taco, smoked kanpachi taco, Baja fish taco, and the aguachile with spot prawn and scallops. The scallop was buttery and sweet, the octopus was super tender with that perfect char, and the smoked kanpachi had this deep, smoky flavor that was just insane. The aguachile was bright, spicy, and refreshing‚Äîperfect for a warm day.

The service was exceptional. You order at the counter, and they somehow manage to bring everything out quickly and perfectly timed, even with so many tables scattered around the market. It‚Äôs impressive how smoothly everything runs.

We finished with the churros and chocolate sauce, which were the perfect ending‚Äîcrispy, light, and the chocolate was rich but not overly sweet.

The small lot is paid (about $4 an hour), but there‚Äôs some free street parking if you get lucky. Definitely worth coming a little early for a spot.

Can‚Äôt wait to come back and try more of the menu, especially anything with uni. This place is a gem. If you're looking for an unforgettable dining experience, Holbox is the place to be. From the moment we walked in, we were greeted with warm, friendly service and a cozy atmosphere that perfectly blends casual with chic. The ambiance set the tone for what would be an amazing meal.

Now, let's talk about the food ‚Äì wow! We tried a variety of tacos, and each one was better than the last. The fish taco was incredibly fresh, with a perfect balance of flavors. The shrimp taco was cooked to perfection, plump and juicy, with just the right amount of seasoning. But the real standout for me was the octopus taco ‚Äì tender and smoky, it had an incredible depth of flavor that really impressed us.

We also had the uni ‚Äì it was beyond amazing. Fresh, creamy, and melt-in-your-mouth delicious, it was a true treat for seafood lovers. Each bite was a reminder of just how high the quality of ingredients is at Holbox.

The tacos alone are worth a visit, but we also couldn‚Äôt resist the cocktails, which were perfectly crafted and paired so well with the meal. The staff was attentive but never overbearing, and we felt like they genuinely cared about our experience.

Overall, Holbox is one of those spots where you know you‚Äôre going to get high-quality food and service every time. I‚Äôll definitely be coming back to try more of their delicious dishes ‚Äì it‚Äôs worth every penny! Due to the high demand, there wasn‚Äôt a meticulous practice on keeping the stations, food prep, and cross contamination clean. Arguably one of the best restaurants I‚Äôve ever been to. Michelin starred for five years and rightfully so. There‚Äôs no glitz and glam just straightforward amazing food. It‚Äôs located in a food hall/market so you order at the counter and they bring the food to you, but there are a few counter seats available as well.
Everything was super fresh, which you can tell by the fresh fish that are on display in the cooler right behind the chefs. The staff is very helpful and attentive. We spoke with one of the owners Briana and you can tell she has a true passion for what she does.
We went here three nights in a row, not for lack of restaurant options as there are plenty to choose from in Los Angeles, but because it was just an amazing experience all around.
We tried the scallop Agua Chile, several of the tostadas, all the tacos, the grilled kanpachi collars, coctel de camarones, the scallop and Uni ceviche, and several other dishes. Every single, one of them deserves perfect reviews. Their freshly made blue corn tortillas alone are worth the trip.
Prices are very modest and won‚Äôt break the bank for the quality of food and service that you receive. Add this to your must try list for the next time you‚Äôre in LA. Went here on a Friday afternoon at opening. There was already a line to get in. However, you can also sit at the counter and get table service there. I found an empty seat and took advantage. It's located in a food court, so expect a packed house.

I was helped quickly by a gentleman. I started off with a sparkling lemonade and a taco de pulpo en su tinta. The taco was very good. The octopus was tender and went well with the calamari ink sofrito. Next I got a tostada de atun. Bluefin tuna, avocado puree and arbol peanut sauce. The combination of all 3 were great! And the homemade tostada was easy to eat. Didn't crumble at any bites, so you're enjoying every component of the plate. Lastly, I got an entr√©e of pulpo a la brasa. The smokiness of the octopus combined with the almond pipian was spot-on! Combine that to make a taco with the baby tomatoes and avocado slices it was a perfect combo!

Overall, a great experience at $57.00. The server was attentive, although his attitude changed after my 15% tip. It's all good. Doesn't take away from the overall experience. I highly recommend coming here. Service Dine in Meal type Lunch Price per person $50‚Äì100 Food: 5 Service: 5 Atmosphere: 4

Wife and I went for early dinner around 3:30 on Sunday (1/19/25). Got a parking spot right away. There was already a 20 deep line just for Holbox. Ordered around 4 pm the grilled octopus plate (pulpo a las brasas), grilled kanpachi collars and a cold halibut tostada (tostada de lenguado). Attentive servers delivered chips and salsa right away. Food started arriving in 20 minutes. Halibut tostada was awesome and fresh. Octopus plate with habanero sauce was just the best...no rubbery morsel here!!! My wife thoroughly enjoyed the fish collar. In between, the wait staff were quick to add a baja fish taco my wife wanted to try. I would go back just to have the same dishes let alone try other items on the menu!! Gave ambiance only 4 stars because Holbox wasn't the only restaurant in the mercado plaza...but it was the primary attraction. BTW, when we left around 5:30 the line was even longer!! My husband and I recently had the pleasure of dining at Holbox for lunch during a whirlwind weekend in LA, and I can confidently say that the experience was nothing short of spectacular! The food was absolutely delightful‚Äîeach dish was succulent and bursting with flavor, leaving me craving more.

While we started with the classic guacamole, we also tried the Baja and shrimp tacos simply because the line moved so fast we didn't get a chance to review the menu. Holbox operates like a well-oiled machine, ensuring fast and attentive service that perfectly complements the delightful food. I was particularly impressed with the portions of the seafood soup, and the smoked kampachi tostado was a treat for anyone who enjoys that rich, smoky flavor. However, the true stars of the meal were the bluefin ceviche and the kampachi and uni tostado. They were so exquisite that, despite being full, I simply couldn‚Äôt help but savor every last bite. A big thank you to Gilberto for recommending the ceviche‚Äîit was a highlight of my culinary adventure!

As I left, I found myself already planning a return trip to try the abalone, lobster, and octopus. A girl can only eat but so much in one sitting. üòÜ

Holbox Los Angeles is an exceptional culinary destination that delivers a high-quality dining experience, worthy of its Michelin star. Nestled within Mercado la Paloma, a historic landmark brimming with culture and a variety of unique food offerings, this restaurant provides a unique and memorable dining experience.

I began my meal with the Taco de pulpo en su tinta, a delightful dish featuring braised and fried Gulf of Mexico octopus. The octopus was tender and perfectly cooked, enhanced by the rich, savory calamari ink sofrito. The depth of flavor in this dish was outstanding, with each bite revealing a nuanced blend of textures and tastes that truly highlighted the quality of the ingredients.

Next, I indulged in the Scallop taco, a masterpiece of pan-seared Maine diver scallops. The scallops were succulent and cooked to perfection, accompanied by a vibrant salsa "x'catic" that added a touch of heat. The caramelized onions, tomato, and marinated fennel provided a sweet and tangy contrast, elevating the overall flavor profile of the dish. The combination of these elements created a harmonious and sophisticated taste that lingered pleasantly on the palate.

The C√≥ctel mixto was another highlight, featuring a mix of wild Mexican shrimp, Gulf of Mexico octopus, and Baja bay scallop. The seafood was fresh and succulent, and the house-made sweet and sour cocktail sauce added a refreshing and zesty touch. The balance of sweetness and acidity in the sauce complemented the natural flavors of the seafood beautifully, making this dish a refreshing and satisfying option.

The ambiance at Holbox is charming and laid-back, set within the vibrant environment of Mercado la Paloma. The market itself is a treasure trove of cultural experiences, offering a diverse array of food choices. It's a great place to explore and soak in the rich cultural tapestry of Los Angeles.

Holbox's approach to customer service is unique, with a casual system where food and drinks are dropped off at your table, rather than traditional waiter service. This setup adds to the relaxed atmosphere, allowing diners to enjoy their meal at their own pace without the formality of a traditional restaurant.

Overall, my experience at Holbox was delightful. Each dish showcased a thoughtful blend of high-quality ingredients and innovative flavors, making it clear why this establishment has earned a Michelin star. The ambiance and service add to the experience, making it a must-visit for anyone looking to explore the rich culinary landscape of Los Angeles. My boyfriend and I got the ceviche de at√∫n, tostada de kanpachi + uni, erizo (live sea urchin with scallop), pata de mula (blood clams), and scallop aguachile.

The ceviche, tostada, and aguachile all had a repetitive flavor profile, with a heavy emphasis on citrus. It felt like we were tasting variations of the same dish, which got a little boring. The blood clams were a hard pass for me--they tasted like mole and just didn't sit well. The erizo was underwhelming; I was hoping for something more exciting.

One odd thing was the accompanying packets of crackers they gave with nearly all the dishes‚Äîthey just didn‚Äôt work well at all. I think these dishes are much better with tortilla chips instead. On the plus side, the food comes out quickly, and the line can get long, but it moves fairly fast. Just a heads-up that the service is kind of non-existent; it's pretty much self-serve. You have to get your own water, hot sauce, and napkins. When we asked one of the food runners for more napkins, she said yes but never came back.

The freshness of the seafood here is undeniable, but I wouldn't recommend going out of the way to try this place. Food: 3 Service: 2 Atmosphere: 2

The ceviche, tostada, and aguachile all had a repetitive flavor profile, with a heavy emphasis on citrus. It felt like we were tasting variations of the same dish, which got a little boring. The blood clams were a hard pass for me--they tasted like mole and just didn't sit well. The erizo was underwhelming; I was hoping for something more exciting.

One odd thing was the accompanying packets of crackers they gave with nearly all the dishes‚Äîthey just didn‚Äôt work well at all. I think these dishes are much better with tortilla chips instead. On the plus side, the food comes out quickly, and the line can get long, but it moves fairly fast. Just a heads-up that the service is kind of non-existent; it's pretty much self-serve. You have to get your own water, hot sauce, and napkins. When we asked one of the food runners for more napkins, she said yes but never came back.

The freshness of the seafood here is undeniable, but I wouldn't recommend going out of the way to try this place. Food: 3 Service: 2 Atmosphere: 2

Chef Gilberto Cetina draws deeply from his Yucat√°n roots to create a seafood-marisquer√≠a experience that feels both authentic and elevated. The menu features ceviches, tostadas, aguachiles and tacos, all built around fresh, well-sourced local seafood with bold citrus, chile and brine flavors.

Located inside Mercado La Paloma in South-Central L.A., a food-hall environment, Holbox is unpretentious and energetic but still delivers on incredible high-end cooking.

The restaurant has earned major recognition: a Michelin star (2024) and a ranking in the top echelon of LA and North America‚Äôs best restaurants.

Reservations are an absolute must and are next to impossible to get given the limited number of counter seats. A fair amount of persistence will be required to dine here.

For those in LA craving top-tier seafood, a pilgrimage to Holbox is an absolute must. Note that service is brisk and all dishes are served at the same time. Portions are also substantial so be sure to come hungry! Meal type Dinner Price per person $100+ Food: 5 Service: 5 Atmosphere: 5 Wait time No wait

Definitely worth doing a little drive to get to this elevated food court and trying Holbox. This is some of the city‚Äôs best fresh Mexican cuisine, with a focus on seafood.

Do yourself a favor and order a bunch of stuff, it‚Äôs worth it. We got: Branzino, Scallop Aguachile, fresh Santa Barbara Uni, Kanpachi & Uni Tostada, Kanpachi Taco, and Baja Fish Taco.

Overall, whatever you do, get the Scallop Aquachile and something with Sea Urchin. By far, probably the best Sea Urchin I‚Äôve had in my life. The Smoked Kampachi Taco was quite good too, it had a peanut chili oil (Salsa Macha) which I‚Äôve never seen before until here. Really cool.

The Branzino was fresh and cooked perfectly, with insanely good blue corn tortillas to go alongside. The Baja Fish taco was pretty standard.

All in all, I try to come here every time I come to LA now. You get FRESH FRESH FISH here and it shows. Recently, there‚Äôs been lines out the door. Worth the wait, I think, but maybe come at a weird time and you won‚Äôt have to worry.

Came here with a friend for lunch on Friday and this place totally deserves its Michelin star. We got there about 15 minutes before opening, so parking was easy and we were part of the first group in line.

Holbox serves Yucat√°n-style seafood tacos, and every single one we tried was incredible. We ordered the scallop taco, octopus taco, smoked kanpachi taco, Baja fish taco, and the aguachile with spot prawn and scallops. The scallop was buttery and sweet, the octopus was super tender with that perfect char, and the smoked kanpachi had this deep, smoky flavor that was just insane. The aguachile was bright, spicy, and refreshing‚Äîperfect for a warm day.

The service was exceptional. You order at the counter, and they somehow manage to bring everything out quickly and perfectly timed, even with so many tables scattered around the market. It‚Äôs impressive how smoothly everything runs.

We finished with the churros and chocolate sauce, which were the perfect ending‚Äîcrispy, light, and the chocolate was rich but not overly sweet.

The small lot is paid (about $4 an hour), but there‚Äôs some free street parking if you get lucky. Definitely worth coming a little early for a spot.

Can‚Äôt wait to come back and try more of the menu, especially anything with uni. This place is a gem. After a serious ceremony at Malibu Beach, I decided to have something special. Then the nightmare started. It was only about 28 miles, but I spent almost two hours to arrive at Holbox. I don't know why the traffic was so horrible that day, or maybe it was just as normal as every day.

For friends who know me, I don't go to fine dining frequently. I had too much fine dining back in Shanghai. I'd rather find interesting dining spots--inside food courts, at food trucks, etc. Holbox is a Michelin one-star restaurant, but not pricey. Even though it's in a food court and not a traditional restaurant, it's interesting. The food booth doesn't have its own tables in the food court; they're shared with others.

It's a Mexican food booth. The boss lady--puebla in Spanish--was tough, but not rude. As with most Michelin spots, there was a queue, but it wasn't too long. I grabbed a table stand and found us a place to sit.

Not long after, the food was served. The free tortilla chips had no shining points--just as normal as in every Mexican restaurant. Crispy, flat dipping, better than nothing. Good for snacking after a long drive.

The food was served one by one, or you could say delivered one by one:

Erizo 5/5
The word erizo in Spanish means hedgehog, but it can also mean sea urchin. They actually look quite similar. Basically, it's sea urchin. Not everyone likes it--some love it, some hate it. I'm a big fan, uni in Japanese. There were two sea urchins, each with about four or five roes. Underneath were fish and scallop ceviches, but different from normal ceviche--it was lighter, without vinegar or lemon taste, more pure raw seafood. I liked it. Not cheap at $27 for an appetizer.

Taco de Pulpo en su Tinta (Octopus Taco) 5/5
Basically, it's an octopus taco, mixed with squid ink or cuttlefish in--I couldn't tell. The ink mostly gave it color, with just a faint hint of the sea for flavor. Each taco had a giant octopus tentacle--three tacos on a plate, one tentacle for each. The texture was excellen--soft, tender, not juicy but still moist, not fishy at all. I bet the octopus was stewed for a long time, which made it so tasty. Very good. $7 for three, which I wouldn't call expensive--actually well priced.

Pescado a las Brasas 5/5
Fish, who doesn't like fish? A few-bone fish, no tiny bones. The seabass had only one big bone but no tiny bones between the muscles. It was grilled seabass, not heavily marinated but well seasoned. The freshness was its biggest strength.

Cilantro Rice and Black Beans 5/5
The rice was served with the grilled seabass, dipped in stewed black beans. I had never tried that before, but it was tasty. Not too much cilantro aroma, but still good. The rice itself was perfectly cooked--grains separated, not sticky. Paired with the black beans, it was a great match.

I recommend this food booth in the food court, not only because of its Michelin crown, but also for the way they used squid/cuttlefish ink, how they treated cilantro, lemon, and avocado. They truly put heart into making good food. Ordered for two people:
- Tostada de mero $11
- Scallop aguachile $16
- Ceviche mixto $20
- Smoked kanpachi taco $7
- Scallop taco $5
- Filete al carbon $16
- Onsite parking: < $3 for one hour
- Total: about $90, or ~$45/person with leftovers

The aguachile and ceviche had the same mild flavor but with different proteins, so it would have been sufficient to have ordered one or the other. The octopus in the ceviche was tender unlike other places that are rubbery and hard to chew, nor was it fishy, so you know it's fresh.

The kanpachi taco was a bit too salty.

The green rice that came with the filete al carbon was surprisingly tasty and actually one of our favorite parts.

The salsas are extremely spicy (rare and appreciated) and best to use as a few droplets rather than lather over the tacos.

As for the experience, we had read that the lines would be long and went with flexible expectations and acknowledged that it was a possibility we may arrive and not have a chance to try it. Arrived around 11:30 AM on a Thursday and the line was out the door. The parking lot and street parking were full and people there said it would be about an hour wait so we got a printed menu to go (since it changes every day). We did not feel comfortable leaving our cars so far away from view so we stayed inside it, reviewed the menu, called to order, and waited 45 minutes for the food. When we returned to pick up the food, we managed to get a parking spot as a person left. We chose parking for one hour for around $2.75 since 2 hours was around $8. Since it's a food court, we were able to eat our "to-go" food anywhere except at the Holbox bar.

This was our first Michelin star experience and probably one of the most affordable options out there, so we'll definitely recommend it for budget-conscious people looking for exceptionally fresh and quality ingredients. However, the flavor itself was pretty mild and parking is extremely limited, so be prepared to pay with your time (maybe get in line first at 10:30 AM before it opens). Finally got to experience Holbox, and it lived up to the hype. Located inside a food hall, the line can stretch out the door depending on when you arrive, but the counter service setup moves efficiently.

We ordered: Tostada de Kanpachi & Uni, Sea Urchin, Scallop Aguachile, Smoked Kanpachi Taco, Taco de Pulpo, Blood Clams, and Langosta al Carb√≥n.

Everything was fresh and delicious. The standouts were the tostada, uni, smoked Kanpachi taco, and the grilled lobster. The Uni was fresh and buttery, served in its shell with scallop and an aioli-like sauce of somekind, mouthwatering. Lobster was grilled evenly, pre broken, served with melted butter, avocado tomatoes, and what can go wrong with a live lobster? Nothing, and they weighed the lobster in front of us, let us snap photos despite being so busy which was sweet of them. The smoked kanpachi taco was great with tender fish and a crunchy blue corn shell. The only dishes we wouldn‚Äôt order again were the blood clams, and octopus taco. The taco was chewy and the clams just didn't stand out among the rest.

The food came out as it was ready, so pacing wasn‚Äôt ideal, but understandable for this kind of spot.

All in all, Holbox is absolutely worth a visit. Just try not to get distracted by the empty stalls around it lol Meal type Lunch Price per person $50‚Äì100 Food: 5 Service: 4 Atmosphere: 4 Noise level Moderate noise Wait time 10-30 min

Came in with high hopes due to the Michelin rating and was not disappointed. My wife and I decided to do a huge sampling of whatever caught our eye on the menu.

The Spot Prawn and Scallop Aguachile was super fresh (prawns grabbed right out of the tank) and refreshing. The lime cilantro chile sauce was crisp and tasty with a hint of heat. Great summer dish.

Being a huge ceviche fan we had the Ceviche de Atun. The bluefin tuna was superb. Another well balanced crisp dish that you couldn‚Äôt stop eating.

The star of our meal though was the Tostada de Kanpachi & Uni. An absolute masterpiece. Beautifully layered textures and tastes. The uni was like icing on the cake to some amazing flavors. Even the tostada had amazing flavor. Would come back just for this dish!

The Pulpo a las Brasas was a pick of mine as I am a sucker for octopus. Super tender with a light char and smokiness. Not sure what the sauce was underneath but it was velvety smokey deliciousness. Even the side of cilantro rice and beans were top notch.

Tacos: We had the Baja Fish Taco and the Smoked Kanpachi Taco. Best fish taco I have ever had in my life. Fish was crisp and not greasy. Perfect amount of crema and salsa. The Kanpachi taco was delicious as well but the Baja taco was just a masterpiece of a taco staple. One thing that got my attention in both was the blue corn tortillas. This is what a tortilla is supposed to be. Never had such delicious tortillas in my life. Crazy how the smallest part of the dish can hold up everything and compete in flavor with the exotic ingredients.

Also enjoyed: we had the sparkling lemonade (tasted more like orange to me). Whatever was in it was amazing and refreshing. Not too sweet.

Pricing: who cares. I thought for the level of execution and the quality of ingredients the dishes would be a value at even a higher price point. Great value in my eyes.

First time at Holbox, and boy! It was delightful. The prices are fair for the freshness of the food cooked and serviced here. I ended up getting the Uni and Pulpo de las Brasas.

The color of the uni was vibrant, fresh, buttery, and melted in your mouth. It is served with the sea urchin and has scallops inside.

The pulpo was cooked just right! It was not hard, nor chewy. Plenty of flavor, and the dish is served with pesto rice, black beans, avocado and cherry tomatoes mixed with purple onions and a grilled lemon on the side.

For drink, I went with the sparkling lemonade, and it was so refreshing!

If you're looking for an unforgettable dining experience, Holbox is the place to be. From the moment we walked in, we were greeted with warm, friendly service and a cozy atmosphere that perfectly blends casual with chic. The ambiance set the tone for what would be an amazing meal.

Now, let's talk about the food ‚Äì wow! We tried a variety of tacos, and each one was better than the last. The fish taco was incredibly fresh, with a perfect balance of flavors. The shrimp taco was cooked to perfection, plump and juicy, with just the right amount of seasoning. But the real standout for me was the octopus taco ‚Äì tender and smoky, it had an incredible depth of flavor that really impressed us.

We also had the uni ‚Äì it was beyond amazing. Fresh, creamy, and melt-in-your-mouth delicious, it was a true treat for seafood lovers. Each bite was a reminder of just how high the quality of ingredients is at Holbox.

The tacos alone are worth a visit, but we also couldn‚Äôt resist the cocktails, which were perfectly crafted and paired so well with the meal. The staff was attentive but never overbearing, and we felt like they genuinely cared about our experience.

Overall, Holbox is one of those spots where you know you‚Äôre going to get high-quality food and service every time. I‚Äôll definitely be coming back to try more of their delicious dishes ‚Äì it‚Äôs worth every penny! Holbox is hands down one of the best seafood spots in LA. We tried the ceviche mixto, taco de pulpo, smoked kanpachi taco, and the tostada de kanpachi with uni ‚Äî everything was incredibly fresh and bursting with flavor.

Even with a line, the wait wasn‚Äôt bad, and the staff went above and beyond. A team member kindly made sure we got seats at the bar without us even asking again ‚Äî it felt like they were really looking out for us. The chefs were friendly, knowledgeable, and proud of their craft. They took time to explain dishes and even let me sample the aguachile sauce based on my spice preference.

The ambiance is casual, market-style, but the energy and passion from the staff make it feel special. Watching someone deliver fresh fish straight into the kitchen was the cherry on top. Big thanks to the entire Holbox team ‚Äî you made our visit unforgettable! In a food court renovated from an industrial plant near USC, this is one of dozens of food stalls and the most popular one. It was awarded a Michelin star in 2024 and won the Plate Award or Bib Gourmand in previous years. I just came back from South America, so I skipped ceviche, the national dish of South America and Mexico. In addition to the must-order scallops and sea urchins for every table, I strongly recommend "Scallop Aguachile", which is scallop chili soup with avocado. A dozen delicious scallops surround the avocado cut into a flower shape, and it is very delicious when soaked in chili sauce. Next time I should try octopus tacos. Undoubtedly the best seafood in Los Angeles and finally getting their much deserved Michelin star in 2024. I have been wanting to visit Holbox for over two years but never had the chance until now.

It‚Äôs all about fresh seafood with a very latin flavor. Several kinds of ceviches, tacos, and tostadas gave the menu away.  That sweet and citrusy scallop aquachile made me wanted to drink the rest of the juice , and how about an octopus taco (blew my mind away) we just got back from Lisbon and this was equally great.  As food were prepared we just kept saying ‚Äúwow‚Äù as they pass us by we‚Äôll have that next time.  If only we had bigger stomachs but there is always a next time.  And those churros for dessert was so good it brought us back to our favorite churros in Seville.  Located inside a food hall surrounded by equally great latin faire reminds me of a small hawker center in Singapore minus the satay grills. Chef Celina definitely upped the ante and has been consistent in his quality since 2017.

Ok, I didn't expect too much from a restaurant with a walk-up counter, and after spending a half-hour waiting in line, my first visit, I was curious what the buzz in the air was. We found a seat in the food court, and a short time later my grilled octopus dinner plate, my wife's three tacos, and the sea urchin and scallop ceviche arrived. Looks impressive, but would it hit the mark?
YES!!! I must say the food far surpassed any expectations I may have had!!!  So much so, I took the 30-mile trip from home again last weekend to try some more Holbox food. This time, I enjoyed the mixed seafood cocktail and three tacos (Baja, aged hamachi, and octopus). My wife went for the grilled octopus plate.
In one word, YUM!!!
It will not be long before we return again!
I rank the food as a 5, the service as a 4 (only because I prefer sit-down and waiter service,  and atmosphere a 3 because I think this food deserves a classier spot, but for the quality of the fare, you can't beat the price!

Arguably one of the best restaurants I‚Äôve ever been to. Michelin starred for five years and rightfully so. There‚Äôs no glitz and glam just straightforward amazing food. It‚Äôs located in a food hall/market so you order at the counter and they bring the food to you, but there are a few counter seats available as well.
Everything was super fresh, which you can tell by the fresh fish that are on display in the cooler right behind the chefs. The staff is very helpful and attentive. We spoke with one of the owners Briana and you can tell she has a true passion for what she does.
We went here three nights in a row, not for lack of restaurant options as there are plenty to choose from in Los Angeles, but because it was just an amazing experience all around.
We tried the scallop Agua Chile, several of the tostadas, all the tacos, the grilled kanpachi collars, coctel de camarones, the scallop and Uni ceviche, and several other dishes. Every single, one of them deserves perfect reviews. Their freshly made blue corn tortillas alone are worth the trip.
Prices are very modest and won‚Äôt break the bank for the quality of food and service that you receive. Add this to your must try list for the next time you‚Äôre in LA. Hidden Gem That Earned Its Star ‚Äì Holbox, Los Angeles

IG: the_hungry_emil

I've been dining at¬†Holbox¬†inside Paloma Market for years, well before it earned its Michelin star, and it's been consistently exceptional every single time.

This visit began with the¬†Halibut Tostada, showcasing incredibly fresh fish over a smooth avocado pur√©e with vibrant pico de gallo‚Äîlight, crisp, and full of flavor.

Next up, the¬†Scallop Aguachile¬†truly impressed. Raw scallops were sweet and briny, perfectly balanced by a zesty green chile-lime sauce, and beautifully presented with red onions and an avocado rose.

I then sampled a trio of tacos:

The¬†Octopus Taco¬†was unlike any I‚Äôve had‚Äîtender grilled octopus served on a deep, savory squid ink sofrito with bright bursts of tomato and chive.

The¬†Scallop Taco¬†featured a seared scallop, lightly caramelized on the outside, paired with a peppery sauce and shredded lettuce for freshness.

The¬†Smoked Kampachi Taco¬†came in a crisp shell, delivering a subtle smokiness to the cooked yellowtail‚Äîunique and absolutely delicious.

Every dish reflects a careful blend of traditional Baja flavors with modern technique and elegance. Holbox is a must-visit for anyone who loves Mexican seafood done right‚Äîand elevated to fine-dining standards. The first time I tried holbox in 2023 I was blown away. The food was so incredible and beautiful, and it was insane for the price. In multiple visits I think it's still amazing but sometimes a bit hit or miss. Favs: scallop aguachile, octopus tacos. Pro tip: get a watermelon agua fresca from the stand across the way for the spice. And the Asian spot has great noodles for kids. Had an amazing time here, truly the best bang for your buck for fresh, authentic Mexican seafood in LA that is, yes, Michelin starred! In additional to sampling a few tacos and tostadas (I prefer the tacos in terms of the vehicle for the seafood - the tortilla is really soft and supple), we also splurged on the uni, which came freshly cracked open and loaded with scallop. What also shocked me was how good the DESSERT was - one of the best churros I've ever had, pillowy and the chocolate sauce was just the right consistency and sweetness. Service was great and there was plenty of seating in the food hall. Overall, an excellent meal! Service Dine in Meal type Dinner Price per person $20‚Äì30 Recommended dishes Churros Con Chocolate

Came here on a Sunday and joined the line around 11:15, before they opened and the line was already out the door. Ordered by 11:50 and got my food by noon. If you're going to come here, aim for off-peak hours or come early. Got the Ceviche Mixto, Kanpachi and Uni Tostada, and Baja Fish Taco. Everything was perfect. Their octopus and scallop are exceptional. Everything else was honestly on par with other good, non-Michelin taco spots.

I will say, only the line is a long wait. After your order, they actually bring your food out pretty quickly, and they'll bring it out as it's ready. Plenty of seating inside and outside, you don't need to be one of those people who save a table before you've even ordered. What can one say about Holbox? It is in a big food court. It has gotten a lot of press, and has a Michelin star. I will start with the food, but I have a lot to say about the experience.

You can upload the menu on your phone or get someone in your group to grab a menu. It is good to use your wait time in the long line to the ordering counter wisely. Send others to grab drinks from another vendor. Buy a few tacos from another vendor if you are hungry.

We tried a lot of dishes. The Baja shrimp taco is traditional, but the shrimp are huge and moist, and the crema and toppings are great. Also quite good was the tostado de jurel. It is yellowtail ceviche, avocado, and an almond salsa on a very crispy corn tortilla base. It was fresh, sour, savory, and yummy. I found the scallop aguachile to be a bit too lime forward, which tends to drown out the sweetness of scallops, but if you eat it with the pieces of avocado and chips, it mellows everything out. Needless to say, all the seafood is bright and fresh.

My companions really loved the smoked kanpachi tacos, all hot and cheesy, and spicy. The camarones al mojo were sensational. This is a main dish platter, so comes with excellent black beans and cilantro rice, plus toasted bread for sopping up the marinade. The shrimp were HUGE and perfectly prepared. So all in all, the food is terrific.

So the downsides: You will pretty much have a 30 to 45 minute wait before you can order. You will need to hunt out a table in the loud, noisy, and not very clean dining hall. The food comes out in no particular order. This makes the actual dining rather chaotic. Our 6 items cost over $100. Michelin star or not, to me, how I am served and the atmosphere in which I eat makes a difference. Is the food great? Yes. Does eating it amid the chaos make it less nice? Yes, absolutely.

I have eaten at a lot of Michelin started restaurants all over the world. Does this rate a Michelin star? I don't think so. But I do recommend eating here. The food is just terrific. We drove all the way from Lake Forest to try Hobox, recently awarded a Michelin star, and located in a food court. There was a line stretching to the door, but it moved fairly quickly. After ordering, we grabbed a number and found a seat by the door. Unfortunately, things took a turn when the line was moved inside, right next to our table. It was loud and awkward to eat with people standing so close, so we had to relocate mid-meal. Thankfully, shortly after we moved, they relocated the line back outside to address the same concerns other diners had.

As for the food, we started with the sparkling lemonade, which was wonderfully bubbly with a perfectly balanced sweet and acidic flavor. It tasted freshly squeezed with no artificial coloring, giving it a very homemade feel.

Next, we received complimentary chips and salsa. The chips were freshly fried and crunchy, but the salsa was a bit too acidic for my taste.

We ordered the uni and kanpachi tostada, which had simple yet effective flavors of salt, pepper, and lime juice that allowed the freshness of the fish and uni to really shine.

The ceviche mixto had a similar flavor profile‚Äîsalt, pepper, lime juice, finely chopped onions, tomatoes, cilantro, and a mix of fresh fish, shrimp, and octopus. While the seafood was undeniably fresh, I found it too salty and lacking in umami. A touch of sweetness and more depth would have made it more enjoyable. The tostada that accompanied the ceviche was light, airy, and perfectly crunchy‚Äînot your typical tostada, which was a nice surprise.

For the tacos, the scallop tacos were absolutely delicious. The scallops were tender, and the pickled onions and grilled cherry tomatoes added just the right amount of acidity to balance the dish. The octopus tacos were the highlight. Perfectly cooked octopus paired with calamari ink sofrito created an unforgettable dish‚Äîone of the best octopus taco I‚Äôve ever had. They did forget to remove the bay leaf from the sofrito, though I‚Äôm not sure if that was intentional.

We also tried the Taco de Pescado al Carbon, featuring mesquite grilled Baja California kanpachi, mayo, morita sauce, cabbage, pico de gallo, and avocado puree. The fish was tender, but the skin was a little too chewy for my taste‚ÄîI would have preferred it to be crunchier.

The shrimp tacos, while decent, didn‚Äôt particularly stand out. They featured battered fried shrimp, garnish, and mayo, which was good but nothing extraordinary.

Overall, it was a great experience trying unique dishes, and I‚Äôd definitely return. Next time, I‚Äôll stick to the hot tacos and skip the ceviche unless they add more umami. Food: 4 Service: 4 Atmosphere: 3

‚ÄúA Culinary Symphony: Tacos that Transcend Reality!‚Äù

Oh, Holbox, you ethereal beacon of culinary excellence! Nestled within the vibrant Mercado La Paloma, this unassuming gem has redefined my understanding of what it means to truly live. I came here for a simple business meeting, but little did I know, I was about to embark on a gastronomic journey so profound that it would forever change the way I perceive the humble taco.

Let me start with the fish tacos‚Äîoh, the fish tacos! These aren‚Äôt just tacos, my friends; these are divine creations, descended from the heavens, kissed by the sea, and delivered to your plate with the grace of a thousand angels. The fish, perfectly crisp on the outside, yet tender and succulent within, was embraced by a tortilla so divine it could be the fabric of the gods themselves. And that ceviche? A burst of oceanic bliss that sent my taste buds into an ecstatic frenzy, dancing and singing praises to the culinary gods!

I found myself utterly mesmerized, unable to focus on the matters of business at hand. My associate, equally ensnared by the spell of Holbox, could only nod in agreement as we devoured these masterpieces in a shared state of euphoria.

But, alas, the path to paradise is not without its trials. The parking situation? A labyrinthine ordeal, forcing me to traverse nearly 300 meters from my vehicle to the gates of this culinary Eden. The prices? Not for the faint of heart, but let me assure you, every single penny was worth the price of admission to this nirvana of flavor.

And yes, the wait‚Äîoh, the wait‚Äîwas long and torturous. Yet, like a true pilgrimage, the reward at the end was nothing short of transcendent. This is one of those rare places where the hype is not just met but exceeded in every possible way.

So, to all my fellow food lovers, hear me now: Being a foodie may be a euphemism for being a little greedy, but at Holbox, it‚Äôs an indulgence that will feed your soul. Go forth, and eat those tacos, my friends. Eat those tacos!

Location: 3655 S Grand Ave, Ste C9, Los Angeles, CA 90007
Website: Holbox Los Angeles
